moves.2... exd4 3. Qxd4 Nc6 4. Qd1 Bc5 5. Nh3: Here I like d6, and then take the knight if it remains on h3.
moves.5... h6 6. a3 Nf6 7. Bd3 d6 8. Nc3: Taking the knight doubles white's pawns while wrecking the king side castle.
moves.8... Qe7 9. Qf3 Bg4 10. Qg3: While the g pawn is considered poison, black should take care about losing it anyway.
moves.10... Nd4 11. Nf4: If white forces the bishop to move, g7 will be at risk.
moves.11... c6 12. h3 Be6 13. Qxg7 O-O-O 14. Q: If white pushes Nd4 with a pawn, Ba7 is undefended except by Nb5.  Another pawn push and black will want to move BxBe3.
moves.16... Nb5: If Bxa7, Nxa7.  That is why the knight is protecting it.  If Bxb5, Bxe3.  Otherwise free bishop for white.
moves.17. Bxa7 Rhg8: White must move the queen, but e3 looks like a good spot which covers Ba7.
moves.18. Qe3 Nd7 19. O-O-O Rde8 20. Nb6+ Nxb6: Now white can play NxBe6 and pick up Qxh6 in the exchange.
moves.22... f6 23. h4 Bd7 24. Ba5 c5 25. Bxc7: That knight was covering d5.  If Kxc7 white forks the queen with Nd5+.  Here Bg4 lets the queen move OnThe bishop but is easily countered by f3.  Bc6 might be better, but lets white's black bishop escape.
moves.25... Kxc7 26. Nd5+ Kb8 27. Nxe7 Rxe7 28: Oh no, this lines up the rooks for a bishop pin, Bc4.
I like Bc6 better, where a pawn mutually protects the bishop.
